Refuses to answer incriminating questions by invoking the Fifth Amendment.
On the advice of counsel, respectfully declines to answer questions to avoid self-incrimination; cleverly avoids incriminating himself during grand jury questioning.
Successfully navigates legal interrogation without self-incrimination or revealing secrets despite pressure.
His account reveals awareness of the risks others took and the outcomes, showing understanding of the bigger picture, but no indication he made mistakes or showed confusion.
Greets Sally Bugs cordially before immediately shooting him twice in the head
Demonstrates no visible hesitation or remorse about killing Sally Bugs
Firmly asserting in court his long years of honest work despite charges, showing confidence and control over his narrative.
Involvement in blowing up the crane company office as retaliation, demonstrating decisive, strategic, and bold action.
Choosing to maintain silence on others' illegal dealings (e.g., what Boffa does with the money), indicating caution and discretion.
Not having receipts to prove the fairness of his car purchase, suggesting a possible oversight or lack of preparation.
Brings grape juice and prosciutto bread for Russell in prison, shares food and pours grape juice for both.
Sits with Russell despite physical pain and limitations, watches other inmates with empathy.
Acknowledges pain and decline of self and others without complaint or blame.
Has limited outward expression of friendliness or warmth beyond small acts of companionship.
Understood the implications of paying under-market value without proper receipts, demonstrating awareness of the risks and consequences.
Reflected on his past decisions thoughtfully but showed resignation to his fate, indicating a realistic appraisal of his situation.
Adapted to harsh prison conditions and physical ailments without complaint or visible loss of composure, maintaining social interaction with peers.
Carried items (grape juice and prosciutto bread) to share with another inmate, exhibiting care and social skills despite physical limitations.
Did not attempt to visibly challenge or resist limitations such as prison rules against a cane, showing acceptance or lack of assertiveness in self-advocacy.
Stands at his wife’s grave with three grown daughters, supporting himself on two canes.
Peggy stands apart and won’t look at him despite his looks, indicating distance in family relationship.
Moves around his house on canes, emptying ashtrays with his wife’s lipstick marks on the filters.
Sits drinking wine alone, not watching TV, isolated.
Fills pill containers but gets confused and starts over.
Trips and falls at night, unable to get up—showing vulnerability and helplessness.
Sits alone in assisted living lounge separate from others, watching war images quietly.
Struggles with basic daily tasks such as organizing pills, moving around the house on canes, trips and falls, and isolates himself from others.
Shows presence of mind and composure by watching difficult war images alone with sound down low while others are distracted.
Lets someone go ahead of him in line to wait for a particular teller window.
Asks to talk to his daughter Peggy and tries to apologize for not being a good father.
Acknowledges his failings and expresses a desire to protect his family despite his harsh actions.
His daughter tells him they couldn't come to him for problems due to his terrible actions, implying he was not emotionally open or approachable.
Uses aluminum canes to enter the bank, scans the room carefully, waits strategically for a particular teller window, lets someone else go ahead, indicating patience and awareness.
Tries to initiate a conversation with his daughter at the bank despite the teller closing the window, showing persistence but possibly lacking influence or timing.
Asks Dolores to call his daughter to talk and apologizes for not being a good father, demonstrating some emotional insight but revealing uncertainty and helplessness.
Uncertain about what he was protecting his family from when questioned by his daughter, showing confusion and lack of clarity about his own motives.
Appears helpless, hapless, and hopeless in face of family conflict and communication breakdown, indicating a moment of low confidence and skill in personal relations.
Conversations reveal an accepting, reflective attitude toward mortality and life, expressing a desire for some good beyond death.
Calmly selects a casket for himself without fuss or complaints, showing acceptance and straightforwardness in a vulnerable moment.
Chooses an appropriate and modest casket without fuss, showing awareness of practical matters and acceptance of his situation.
Reflects thoughtfully on mortality and the meaning of life and death, indicating intellectual engagement despite declining health.
His calm, measured interaction with the salesman and acceptance of burial costs without complaint shows pragmatic decision-making.
Shows patience and respect by not rushing to decide the casket and considers options thoughtfully.
Welcomes FBI agents at his porch and seems fine having them as visitors.
Acknowledges the pain of Hoffa's children living without knowing the truth, showing awareness of others' suffering.
Refuses to provide information to FBI agents despite seeming to consider telling them, ultimately shutting down communication.
Carefully considers options about burial arrangements without rushing, showing thoughtfulness and reasoned decision-making.
Politely but firmly directs FBI agents to his attorney and refuses to provide any information about Hoffa, maintaining composure and control of the interaction.
Shows momentary hesitation or internal conflict about telling the truth to FBI agents but ultimately withholds information, indicating controlled discretion but possible emotional restraint.

Slowly runs a hand through his hair, hesitates to say the prayer, admits to partial knowledge but willing to participate in prayer, speaks thoughtfully about his feelings (or lack thereof) regarding his past actions and remorse.
Expresses guilt and remorse while looking at Jimmy's photo, and agrees to pray with the priest.
Justifies violent actions as unavoidable, implying resignation rather than cruelty.
Mentions his daughter Peggy and family photographs in a quiet, personal moment with the nurse.
Forces himself to face painful guilt and show faint remnant of humanity despite severe internal conflict and remorse over his actions.
Rationalizes brutal acts as inevitable and necessary for self-preservation, demonstrating pragmatic understanding of dangerous situations.
Avoids revealing full details by saying 'That’s all I can tell ya' when pressed for explanation, maintaining control over information.
Shows emotional vulnerability and remorse, which could be seen as a sign of internal struggle reducing confident decisiveness.
Does not correct the nurse when she fails to recognize Jimmy Hoffa, choosing silence rather than displaying his knowledge.
Engages quietly and patiently with the nurse, complying with her instructions without resistance or confusion.
Uses subtle humor or irony ('You only know how fast time goes when you get there') reflecting a calm and reflective demeanor.
Requests the priest to leave the door slightly open so he is not completely isolated.
Sits alone quietly, leafing through photographs, showing introspection but no engagement.
Recites prayers correctly when prompted by the priest, showing awareness and memory.
Requests the door be left partly open, indicating a thoughtful preference and control over his environment.
Initially does not remember the prayer spontaneously and needs prompting from the priest.
